body.p:
Louisville May 19th 1865
His Excellency.
Thos. E. Bramlette
Governor of Kentucky
Sir.

This letter will be handed you by Miss Mitchell a young lady of high standing in this city. She comes to lay before your Excellency a petition in behalf of her Brother Edward Mitchell who was recently convicted of manslaughter in our Circuit Court.

I would say to you that Edward Mitchell was a private in the Louisville Legion, and fought like a hero and was remarkable for his quiet and orderly deportment. For three years I knew him well, and can cheerfully testify to his worth as a soldier. He did his duty in every battle in which the proud old Legion participated, He is a kind hearted boy, and bitterly regrets what he has done. I am persuaded he will never again suffer himself to be ensnared by that common enemy strong drink, I believe he will yet make a good citizen, and if you can see you way clear to interpose executive clemency it will gladden the hearts of his distressed relatives, and put a brave and heroic youth in a position to redeem the past I most respectfully ask a pardon for him.

Yours truly J H, Bristow
Late Chaplain Louisville Legion
